snippet: Trainers of Kentucky Derby horses say they will take their time in deciding whether to run the second leg of the Triple Crown.
abstract: Kentucky Derby winner I'll Have Another will be shipped to Baltimore to compete in the Preakness, the second leg of the Triple Crown; some trainers are contemplating whether to send their horse to the Preakness without a chance at Triple Crown. Photos (M)/
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Every year, it's the same on the Sunday morning after the Kentucky Derby -- one barn is rocking with a happy trainer and his smiling, bleary-eyed entourage, while the barns of his vanquished rivals are home to tired horses, glum human faces and heavy hearts. Talk of a Triple Crown, of course, was in the air outside the stall of the Derby winner, I'll Have Another. The colt is scheduled to be shipped to Baltimore on Monday to try to win the second leg of racing's holy grail, the Preakness Stakes, on May 19.

headline.main: Race to the Preakness Is Filled With Caution
